RT @RepAdams Happy First Day of School to @CharMeckSchools and all of the students, teachers and staff!

Please be safe as you start your learning journey this year.
Time is running out and we cannot leave our fellow Americans and Afghan allies behind. We need our commander-in-chief to start acting like a leader and use any means necessary to get the job done.

My office is assisting hundreds of people still stranded in Afghanistan and trying the best we can to cut red tape and get them evacuated safely. The situation is dire, we are receiving heartbreaking alerts from SIVs that the Taliban is tracking them and their families down.

Our servicemembers and military leaders are doing an extraordinary job in spite of the limited authority & direction provided to them by the Biden admin. We have seen their sense of duty, urgency, & compassion that we frankly are not consistently seeing from our civilian leaders.

We deserve to know the full extent of the agreement with the Taliban, including the arbitrary and inflexible deadline that led us to the humiliating point of the Taliban dictating terms to the U.S. and setting a red line.

President Biden's disastrous decision not to move the August 31st deadline to evacuate all Americans and Afghans was cemented by his administration’s prior ill-conceived timeline agreement with the Taliban instead of the conditions on the ground.
Science doesn’t change, but our understanding of it does when we conduct experiments and observe the results.

America must not leave Afghanistan until our mission is complete.

I was in middle school when the decision to invade Afghanistan was made and I did not have a say. Now, as a Member of the House Foreign Affairs and Armed Services Committees, I am committed to ensuring we learn the lessons of the last few months, and the past twenty years.
There are many reasons for the challenges we are seeing in Afghanistan today, most of which predate the current President, and they deserve a fulsome policy debate.

The United States has a moral obligation to help the Afghan people. We also owe them, and all those who sacrificed, honesty and humility about the real failures in Afghanistan over the past twenty years.

We must guarantee humanitarian parole, increase the refugee cap & provide assistance to refugees, ensure legal safeguards & funding for organizations that deliver humanitarian assistance, and evacuate as many Americans & vulnerable Afghans as possible before we withdraw.

And while I am disappointed in the execution of the withdrawal and committed to assessing the policy failures in Afghanistan, right now, I am focused on getting as many people to safety as possible and responding to the humanitarian needs of people in Afghanistan.

I continue to support and agree with President Biden’s decision to withdraw from Afghanistan. However, I remain incredibly concerned about the ongoing evacuation process in Kabul and the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Afghanistan.
